at_risk_high_pct.long_description: The percentage of households at high risk of racing food insecurity, based on financial model considering income category and household size. The food security status is determined after comparing household income versus cost-of-living. Cost of living includes eight categories, including food, housing, healthcare, childcare, transportation, taxes, internet, and other expenses. Geographies: Census Tract (11)
at_risk_high_pct.long_name: Estimated percentage of total households classified at high risk of facing food insecurity
at_risk_high_pct.short_name: Food Insecure Population Percentage - High Risk

Child_Food_Insecurity_Rate.long_description: The percentage of food insecure children. Food insecurity refers to the US Department of Agriculture’s (USDA) measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecure children are those children living in households that are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household’s need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods. Geographies: County (5)
Child_Food_Insecurity_Rate.statement: {value} of the population of children in {features.name} are food insecure.

Cost_Per_Meal.long_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food, as estimated by the Current Population Survey, divided by 21 (assuming three meals a day for seven days a week). This amount has been adjusted to reflect local food prices and relevant taxes. Geographies: County (5)
Cost_Per_Meal.statement: The average meal cost in {features.name} is {value}.
Cost_Per_Meal.source_file: https://github.com/uva-bi-sdad/sdc.food/blob/main/Food Security/Feeding America/Food Secure Average Meal Cost/data/distribution/measure_info.json

dent_e2sfca.long_description: Dental care availability based on 2-step enhanced floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of dentists per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for dentists (population served by dentists). Provider address data were collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.
dent_e2sfca.long_name: Dental care geographic availability (2 step-enhanced floating catchment areas)
dent_e2sfca.short_description: Index of dental care availability based on supply and demand of providers
dent_e2sfca.statement: The dental care availability for {features.name} is {value}.

devices.long_description: The number of unique devices accessing Ookla Internet speed tests. Geographies: Block group (12), Census tract (11), County (5), Health Districts (51_hd_xx)
devices.statement: There are {value} unique devices in {features.name} accessing Ookla Internet speed tests.

earnings_per_job.long_description: Earnings per job are calculated based on the GDP and Personal Income table for the Bureau of Economic Analysis (BEA). Earnings per job is the total earnings divided by total number of jobs. Total earnings is the sum of wages and salaries, supplements to wages and salaries, and proprietor’s income. Wages and salaries refer to the monetary remuneration of employees; it includes compensation of corporate officers; commissions, tips, and bonuses, compensation plans, such as a 401(k) plans; and receipts in kind, or pay-in0kind, that represent income to the recipient. Supplements to wages and salaries consist of employer contributions for employee pension and insurance funds and employer contributions for government social insurance. The proprietor’s income is the current-production income (including the income in kind) of sole proprietorships and partnerships and of tax-exempt cooperatives. Geographies: County(5), Health Districts (51_hd)
earnings_per_job.short_description: Earnings per job are calculated based on the GDP and Personal Income table for the Bureau of Economic Analysis (BEA). Earnings per job is the total earnings divided by total number of jobs. Total earnings is the sum of wages and salaries, supplements to wages and salaries, and proprietor’s income. Wages and salaries refer to the monetary remuneration of employees; it includes compensation of corporate officers; commissions, tips, and bonuses, compensation plans, such as a 401(k) plans; and receipts in kind, or pay-in0kind, that represent income to the recipient. Supplements to wages and salaries consist of employer contributions for employee pension and insurance funds and employer contributions for government social insurance. The proprietor’s income is the current-production income (including the income in kind) of sole proprietorships and partnerships and of tax-exempt cooperatives. Geographies: County(5), Health Districts (51_hd)

emp_rate.long_description: Population, self-reported as employed, as a percentage of the total civilian workforce population. Geographies: Census Tract (11), County (5)
emp_rate.short_description: Population, self-reported as employed, as a percentage of the total civilian workforce population. Geographies: Census Tract (11), County (5)

sources.name: American Community Survey
sources.location: 5-Year estimates, table B23025, via the API

emp_rate.statement: {value} of the population in {region_name} is employed.

ems_3sfca.long_description: Emergency medical services availability is based on 3-step floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of facilities per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a facility is accessible). Weights are defined as the demand for facilities (or the adult population). Geographies: Block group (12), Census tract (11), County (5), Civic Associations (51013_ca)
ems_3sfca.long_name: Emergency medical services geographic availability (3-step floating catchment areas)
ems_3sfca.statement: The emergency medical services availability for {features.name} is {value}.

ems_cnt.long_description: Count of emergency medical services facilities based on facility locations. Location data was collected from the Homeland Infrastructure Foundation-Level Data (HIFLD) repository. Geographies: Block group (12), Census tract (11), County (5), Civic Associations (51013_ca)
ems_cnt.long_name: Availability of emergency medical services by count
ems_cnt.statement: There are {value} emergency medical services facilities in {features.name}.

ems_near_10_median.long_description: Median drive time in minutes to the ten closest emergency medical services facilities. Facility location data were collected from the Homeland Infrastructure Foundation-Level Data (HIFLD) repository. Drive times were computer using Open Source Routing Machine (looking at roads for 2021) Geographies: Block group (12), Census tract (11), County (5), Civic Associations (51013_ca)
ems_near_10_median.long_name: Emergency medical services availability by median drive time to the ten closest facilities in minutes
ems_near_10_median.statement: The median drive time to the ten closest emergency medical service facilities to {features.name} is {value}.

food_insecure_cnt.long_description: Estimate of the number of people in food-insecure households. Food insecurity refers to the US Department of Agriculture’s (USDA) measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecurity may reflect a household’s need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods. Geographies: Census tract (11)
food_insecure_cnt.long_name: Estimated number of food insecure people

Geographies: Census tract (11)

hh_received_snap_cnt.long_description: The number of households in which at least one member of the household received benefits from the Food Stamp Program or the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) in the past 12 months. This does not include households in which at least one member received benefits from WIC, the School Lunch Program, or assistance from food banks and not also from the Food Stamp Program or SNAP in the past 12 months. Geographies: Block group (12), Census tract (11), County (5), Health Districts (51_hd)
hh_received_snap_cnt.long_name: Count of Households That Received Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP)
hh_received_snap_cnt.short_name: Count of Households That Received SNAP
hh_received_snap_cnt.statement: The count of households that received SNAP in {features.name} is {value}.
hh_received_snap_cnt.source_file: https://github.com/uva-bi-sdad/sdc.food/blob/main/Food and Nutrition Assistance/Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP)/data/distribution/measure_info.json

Minority_employment.long_description: Count of total employment for racial minority workers. Racial minority in this case is defined as Black alone, American Indian or Alaska Native alone, Asian alone, Hawaii and Pacific Islander alone, or Two or More Races.

sources.location: Origin-Destination Employment Statistics (LODES), Workplace Area Characteristics (WAC)
sources.name: Longitudinal Employer-Household Dynamics (LEHD)

Minority_employment.statement: The number of jobs for racial minority workers in {features.name} is {value}.

monthly_rent_0br.long_description: The Fair Market Rent (FMR) is the 40th percentile of rents.  FMRs are estimated by HUD for metropolitan areas and nonmetropolitan counties.  We used HUD data at the ZIP Code and county levels to compute county and census tract level FMRs.
monthly_rent_0br.short_description: The Fair Market Rent (FMR) is the 40th percentile of rents.

sources.name: US Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD)

monthly_rent_0br.statement: The Fair Market Rent (FMR) for a zero bedroom dwelling in {features.name} is {value}.

monthly_rent_1br.long_description: The Fair Market Rent (FMR) is the 40th percentile of rents.  FMRs are estimated by HUD for metropolitan areas and nonmetropolitan counties.  We used HUD data at the ZIP Code and county levels to compute county and census tract level FMRs.
monthly_rent_1br.short_description: The Fair Market Rent (FMR) is the 40th percentile of rents.

sources.name: US Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD)

monthly_rent_1br.statement: The Fair Market Rent (FMR) for a one bedroom dwelling in {features.name} is {value}.

monthly_rent_2br.long_description: The Fair Market Rent (FMR) is the 40th percentile of rents.  FMRs are estimated by HUD for metropolitan areas and nonmetropolitan counties.  We used HUD data at the ZIP Code and county levels to compute county and census tract level FMRs.
monthly_rent_2br.short_description: The Fair Market Rent (FMR) is the 40th percentile of rents.

sources.name: US Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD)

monthly_rent_2br.statement: The Fair Market Rent (FMR) for a two bedroom dwelling in {features.name} is {value}.

monthly_rent_3br.statement: The Fair Market Rent (FMR) for a three bedroom dwelling in {features.name} is {value}.

mrfei.long_description: The number of available healthy and less healthy food retailers. A higher score indicates more available healthy options per less healthy options. A score of 0 indicates no available options, therefore a food desert. Geographies: Block group (12), Census tract (11), County (5), Civic Association (51013_hd)
mrfei.statement: The Retail food environment index is {value} in {features.name}.

no_hlth_ins_pct.long_description: Percent of the self-reported population not covered by any type of health insurance or health coverage plan. Based on American Community Survey Tables B27010 in ACS 2015/2019 5-year estimates. Geographies: Block group (12), Census tract (11), County (5)
no_hlth_ins_pct.long_name: Percent of population without health insurance
no_hlth_ins_pct.statement: {value} of the population does not have health insurance in {features.name}.

Nonminority_employment.long_description: Count of total employment for racial non-minority workers. Non-minority in this case is defined as White alone.
Nonminority_employment.short_description: Total employment by racial non-minority workers (count)

sources.location: Origin-Destination Employment Statistics (LODES), Workplace Area Characteristics (WAC)
sources.name: Longitudinal Employer-Household Dynamics (LEHD)

Nonminority_employment.statement: The number of jobs for racial non-minority workers in {features.name} is {value}.

Num_Child_Food_Insecure.long_description: The number of food insecure children. Food insecurity refers to the US Department of Agriculture’s (USDA) measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecure children are those children living in households that are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household’s need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods. Geographies: County (5)
Num_Child_Food_Insecure.statement: The population of food insecure children in {features.name} is {value}.

number_food_insecure.long_description: Estimated number of total people in food insecure households according to Feeding America. Food insecurity refers to the US Department of Agriculture’s (USDA) measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. The brief providing the methodology of calculating these estimates is available on Feeding America’s Map the Meal Gap website. Food insecurity may reflect a household’s need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods. Geographies: Census tract (11), County (5), Health Districts (51_hd)
number_food_insecure.long_name: Estimated number of total people in food insecure households

obgyn_e2sfca.long_description: OBGYN care availability based on 2-step enhanced floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of OBGYNs per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for OBGYNs (population served by OBGYNs). Provider address data were collected from WebMD's online physician directory.
obgyn_e2sfca.long_name: OBGYN care geographic availability (2-step enhanced floating catchment areas)
obgyn_e2sfca.short_description: Index of OBGYN care availability based on supply and demand of providers

ped_e2sfca.long_description: Pediatric care availability based on 2-step enhanced floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of pediatricians per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for pediatricians (population under 16). Provider address data were collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.
ped_e2sfca.long_name: Pediatric care geographic availability (2-step enhanced floating catchment areas)
ped_e2sfca.short_description: Index of pediatric care physician availability based on supply and demand of providers
ped_e2sfca.statement: The pediatric care availability for {features.name} is {value}.

per_above30.long_description: The percentage of households whose monthly housing costs from mortgage payments or rent account for 30% or more of their household’s income in the past 12 months.
per_above30.long_name: Percentage of Households Whose Mortgage Payments or Rent Account for 30% or More of Their Household Income
per_above30.short_name: Cost-Burdened Households - Owner-Occupied & Mortgaged, and Renter-Occupied
per_above30.statement: The percentage of households whose monthly housing costs from mortgage payments or rent account for 30% or more of their household income in {features.name} is {value}

per_mor_above30.long_description: The percentage of owner-occupied households whose monthly housing costs from mortgage payments account for 30% or more of their household income in the past 12 months.
per_mor_above30.long_name: Percentage of Owner-Occupied Households Whose Mortgage Payments are 30% or More of Their Household Income
per_mor_above30.short_description: The percentage of owner-occupied households whose mortgage payments are 30% or more of their household income.
per_mor_above30.statement: The percentage of owner-occupied households whose monthly housing costs from mortgage payments account for 30% or more of their household income in {features.name} is {value}

per_rent_above30.long_description: The percentage of renter-occupied households whose monthly housing costs from rent payments account for 30% or more of their household’s income in the past 12 months.
per_rent_above30.long_name: Percentage of Renter-Occupied Households Whose Rent Accounts for 30% or More of Their Household Income
per_rent_above30.statement: The percentage of renter-occupied households whose monthly housing costs from rent account for 30% or more of their household income in {features.name} is {value}

perc_hh_with_broadband.long_description: Percentage of households self-reported to have a broadband internet connection. Broadband internet is defined as any type of internet other than a dial-up. Data is based on American Community Survey Table B28002 in ACS 2015/2019 5-year estimates. Geographies: County (5), Block group (12), Census Tract (11), Health Districts (51_hd_xx)
perc_hh_with_broadband.statement: {value} of households in {features.name} have a broadband connection.

perc_hh_with_cable_fiber_dsl.long_description: Percentage of households self-reported to have a high-speed internet service. A high-speed internet service is defined as a cable, fiber optic, or DSL internet connection. Data is based on American Community Survey Table B28002 in ACS 2015/2019 5-year estimates. Geographies: County (5), Block group (12), Census Tract (11), Health Districts (51_hd_xx)
perc_hh_with_cable_fiber_dsl.long_name: Percentage of households with a high speed internet service (cable, fiber optic, or DSL)
perc_hh_with_cable_fiber_dsl.short_name: Households with cable, fiber optic, or DSL
perc_hh_with_cable_fiber_dsl.statement: {value} of households in {features.name} have a cable, fiber optic, or DSL internet connection.

perc_hh_without_compdev.long_description: Percentage of households self-reported to not have a computer or device at home. Data is based on American Community Survey Table B28001 in ACS 2015/2019 5-year estimates. Geographies: County (5), Block group (12), Census Tract (11), Health Districts (51_hd_xx)
perc_hh_without_compdev.long_name: Percentage of households without a computer
perc_hh_without_compdev.statement: {value} of households in {features.name} do not have a computer or device.

perc_hh_without_internet.long_description: Percentage of households self-reported to not have internet access at home. Data is based on American Community Survey Table B28002 in ACS 2015/2019 5-year estimates. Geographies: County (5), Block group (12), Census Tract (11), Health Districts (51_hd_xx)
perc_hh_without_internet.long_name: Percentage of households without internet access
perc_hh_without_internet.statement: {value} of households in {features.name} do not have internet access.

perc_income_avg_nat_package.long_description: The national average price for internet, which is $64, as a percentage of median household income. Geographies: Block group (12), Census Tract (11), County (5)
perc_income_avg_nat_package.long_name: The national average price for internet as a percentage of average income
perc_income_avg_nat_package.short_description: The national average price for internet ($64) as a percentage of median household income
perc_income_avg_nat_package.statement: The national average internet package costs {value} of the median household income in {features.name}.

perc_income_min_price_100.long_description: TThe minimum price for fast internet (which is defined as 100 MB/s upload) as a percentage of median household income. Geographis: Block group (12), Census Tract (11), County (5)
perc_income_min_price_100.long_name: The minimum price for fast internet (100 MB/s upload) as a percentage of median household income
perc_income_min_price_100.short_description: The minimum price for fast internet (100 MB/s upload) as a percent of median household income
perc_income_min_price_100.short_name: Percentage of income for fast internet

perc_income_min_price_25.long_description: The minimum price for good internet (which is defined as 25 MB/s upload) as a percentage of median household income. Geographies: Block group (12), Census Tract (11), County (5)
perc_income_min_price_25.long_name: The minimum price for good internet (25 MB/s upload) as a percentage of median household income
perc_income_min_price_25.short_description: The minimum price for good internet (25 MB/s upload) as a percentage of median household income
perc_income_min_price_25.short_name: Percentage of income for good internet
perc_income_min_price_25.statement: Good internet costs {value} of the median household income in {features.name}.

percent_food_insecure.long_description: Estimated percentage of total people in food insecure households according to Feeding America. Food insecurity refers to the US Department of Agriculture’s (USDA) measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. The brief providing the methodology of calculating these estimates is available on Feeding America’s Map the Meal Gap website. Food insecurity may reflect a household’s need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods. Geographies: Census tract (11), County (5), Health Districts (51_hd)
percent_food_insecure.long_name: Estimated percentage of total people in food insecure households
percent_food_insecure.statement: {value} percent of the population in {features.name} are food insecure.

population{variant}{category.name}.long_description: {variant} For non-census geographies, values are redistributed {category}, using the redistribute R package.

sources.name: American Community Survey
sources.location: 5-Year estimates, table B01003, via the API

sources.name: Fairfax County Geospatial Data
sources.location: Health & Human Service > Human Services Regions

blank.long_description: Total number of people, as reported in census ACS population data.

_density.long_description: Population density, or number of people per square mile, as calculated from census ACS population data and shapefile areas: \[\frac{population_{r}}{meters^{2}_{r}}1609.344^{2}\] Where r is each region (e.g., census tract or county).

_direct.short_description: estimated by proportional overlap for non-census geographies
_direct.long_description: based on proportional overlap between census block groups and the local regions

_parcels.short_description: estimated by proportional overlap with parcels for non-census geographies
_parcels.long_description: from census block groups to parcels, based on proportional geometric overlap and weighted by number of living units per parcel, then from parcels to the local regions based on proportional geometric overlap

prevent_hosp_rate.long_description: Rate of hospital stays for ambulatory-care sensitive conditions per 100,000 Medicare enrollees. Ambulatory care refers to diagnoses that are usually treatable in outpatient settings. This data is based on Medicare claims and comes from County Health Rankings. Geographies: County (5), Health Districts (51_hd)
prevent_hosp_rate.long_name: Preventable hospital stays per 100,000 Medicare enrollees
prevent_hosp_rate.statement: {value} of the hospitalizations in {features.name} were preventable (due to conditions usually treated in outpatient settings).

primcare_e2sfca.long_description: Primary care availability based on 2-step enhanced floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of physicians per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for physicians (population served by physicians). Provider address data were collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.
primcare_e2sfca.long_name: Primary care geographic availability (2-step enhanced floating catchment areas)
primcare_e2sfca.short_description: Index of primary care physician availability based on supply and demand of providers
primcare_e2sfca.statement: The primary care availability for {features.name} is {value}.

race_{variant.name}{category.name}.long_description: {variant} 5-year ACS estimates in provided census geolevels. For non-census geolevels (such as zip codes), spatial overlaps are calculated between census block groups {category} Redistribution to non-census geolevels was performed using the redistribute R package.

sources.name: American Community Survey
sources.location: 5-Year estimates, table B01001, via the API

sources.name: Fairfax County Geospatial Data
sources.location: Health & Human Service > Human Services Regions

_parcels.long_description: and parcels, then the value of each block group is divided across all living units within each intersecting parcel. Once parcel-level values are assigned, spatial overlaps are calculated between parcels and target regions such that parcel values can be aggregated to each intersecting target region based on proportion of overlap.

_direct.long_description: and target regions, then the value of each block group is aggregated/disaggregated to any intersecting target region based on proportion of overlap.

schools_{variant.name}_min_drivetime.short_description: Drive time to the nearest {variant} schools.
schools_{variant.name}_min_drivetime.long_description: Minimal drive time to a schools authorized to award {variant} from the Census block group centroid, as calculated by the Open Source Routing Machine. School locations are from the National Center for Education Statistics. All distances are calculated at the block group level, then averaged up to higher-level geographies.
schools_{variant.name}_min_drivetime.statement: It takes {value} to drive to the nearest {variant} school from {region_name}'s block group centroids on average.

sources.name: National Center for Education Statistics
sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics

2year.long_description: Associates degrees or 2-year or longer certificates

under2year.long_description: certificates that are typically obtained in less than 2 years

schools_2year_{category.name}.short_description: Number of 2-year schools{category} per 100k people over 14, calculated within floating catchment areas.
schools_2year_{category.name}.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award Associates degrees or 2-year or longer certificates{category} per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) qualifying 2-year schools as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
schools_2year_{category.name}.statement: There are {value} 2-year schools{category} per 100k people over 14 in {region_name}.

sources.name: National Center for Education Statistics
sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics

with_biomedical_program.long_description: with biomedical programs (any with Classification of Institutional Programs [CIP] codes starting with 26)

with_science_program.long_description: with science programs (any with Classification of Institutional Programs [CIP] codes starting with 41)

with_physical_program.long_description: with science programs (any with Classification of Institutional Programs [CIP] codes starting with 40)

with_computer_program.long_description: with science programs (any with Classification of Institutional Programs [CIP] codes starting with 11)

with_engineering_program.long_description: with science programs (any with Classification of Institutional Programs [CIP] codes starting with 14 or 15)

schools_under2year.short_description: Number of <2-year schools per 100k people over 14, calculated within floating catchment areas.
schools_under2year.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award certificates that are typically obtained in less than 2 years per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) <2-year schools as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
schools_under2year.statement: There are {value} <2-year schools per 100k people over 14 in {region_name}.

sources.name: National Center for Education Statistics
sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics

snap_shortfall_weighted_mean.long_description: The average supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) shortfall is the estimated dollar amount that a household lacks to pay for their food costs. SNAP benefit is the dollar amount of money that a household may receive for supplemental food assistance after eligibility. The SNAP shortfall is the ratio between the SNAP benefit divided by the food shortfall money. The weighted average uses the number of households in different income categories, household combinations, and geography, and the average is estimated for every census tract. Geographies: Census Tract (11)

sources.name: U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development
Department   of Labor Women’s Bureau National
National   Bureau of Economic Research’s program TAXSIM Version 35

snap_shortfall_weighted_mean.statement: The average SNAP shortfall for households in {features.name} is {value}.

snap_weighted_mean.long_description: Weighted mean average of the dollar amount of Supplemental Nutrition Assitance Program (SNAP) benefit. The financial benefit is estimated following the guidelines and procedures from the Virginia Department of Social Services. The weighting component corresponds to the number of households in different income categories, household combinations, and geographies. The weighted average is obtained for every census tract. Geographies: Census Tract (11)

sources.name: U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development
Department   of Labor Women’s Bureau National
National   Bureau of Economic Research’s program TAXSIM Version 35

snap_weighted_mean.statement: The average of SNAP benefits for households in {features.name} is {value}.

subs_3sfca.long_description: Substance use/behavioral health services availability is based on 3-step floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of facilities per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a facility is accessible). Weights are defined as the demand for facilities (in the adult population). Geographies: Block group (12), Census tract (11), County (5), Health District (51_hd), Civic Associations (51013_ca)
subs_3sfca.long_name: Substance use/behavioral health services geographic availability (3-step floating catchment areas)
subs_3sfca.short_name: Substance use/behavioral health services geographic availability

sources.name: Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA)

subs_3sfca.statement: The substance use/behavioral health services availability for {features.name} is {value}.

subs_cnt.long_description: Count of substance use/behavioral health facilities based on facility locations. Location data was collected from the Homeland Infrastructure Foundation-Level Data (HIFLD) repository. Geographies: Block group (12), Census tract (11), County (5), Health District (51_hd), Civic Associations (51013_ca
subs_cnt.long_name: Availability of substance use/behavioral health by count

sources.name: Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA)

subs_cnt.statement: There are {value} substance use facilities in {features.name}.

subs_near_10_median.long_description: Median drive time in minutes to the ten closest substance use/behavioral health services facilities. Facility location data were collected from the Homeland Infrastructure Foundation-Level Data (HIFLD) repository. Drive times were computer using Open Source Routing Machine (looking at roads for 2021). Geographies: Block group (12), Census tract (11), County (5), Health District (51_hd), Civic Associations (51013_ca)
subs_near_10_median.long_name: Substance use/behavioral health services availability by median drive time to the ten closest facilities in minutes
subs_near_10_median.short_name: Substance use/behavioral health services availability (drive time)

sources.name: Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA)

subs_near_10_median.statement: The median drive time to the ten closest substance use/behavioral health service facilities to {features.name} is {value}.

urgent_3sfca.long_description: Urgent care availability is based on 3-step floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of facilities per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a facility is accessible). Weights are defined as the demand for facilities (in the adult population). Geographies: Block group (12), Census tract (11), County (5)
urgent_3sfca.long_name: Urgent care geographic availability (3-step floating catchment areas)
urgent_3sfca.statement: The urgent care availability for {features.name} is {value}.

urgent_cnt.long_description: Count of urgent care facilities based on facility locations. Location data was collected from the Google Maps. Geographies: Block group (12), Census tract (11), County (5)
urgent_cnt.long_name: Availability of urgent care by count
urgent_cnt.statement: There are {value} urgent care facilities in {features.name}.

urgent_near_10_median.long_description: Median drive time in minutes to the ten closest urgent care facilities. Facility location data were collected from Google Maps. Drive times were computer using Open Source Routing Machine (looking at roads for 2021). Geographies: Block group (12), Census tract (11), County (5)
urgent_near_10_median.long_name: Urgent care availability by median drive time to the ten closest facilities in minutes
urgent_near_10_median.statement: The median drive time to the ten closest urgent care facilities to {features.name} is {value}.
